Lake Tanganyika Regional Integrated Management Project.

By Thomas Gumbricht Google scholar Researchgate Mendeley Scopus Linkedin Orcid

A United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) / Global Environmental Facility (GEF) project covering the Lake Tanganyika riparian countries, Burundi, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Tanzania and Zambia.

Within the project I organized and led training workshops in Kenya, Tanzania, Zambia and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). I also held the training modules on spatial data analysis and land degradation in each project country.

Presentations

  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, 29 June 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lake Tanganyika Basin Land cover change and degradation hotspots.

Training

  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 10 – Importing , exporting and projecting layers.
  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 9 – Decision support for identifying landscape erosion risk.
  • Oloo, F. & Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 8 – Present and future climate scenario, and modeling species suitability.
  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 7 – Generating slope data.
  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 6 – Rain Normalized NDVI and land degradation hotspots.
  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 5 – Vegetation and time series data.
  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 4 – Grid/raster data.
  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 3 – Selecting features, labeling and designing maps.
  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 2 – Symbolization.
  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 1 – DIVA-GIS basics.
  • Gumbricht, T., ICRAF, October 2010, Nairobi, Kenya 2010. Lesson 0 – Install DIVA GIS.
